column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Create Your Own Dump Recipes

#Text=People are more interested than ever in how to come up with your very own meal dump recipes — recipes which only require you to dump a few ingredients into a pot , pressure cooker or crock-pot and then cook those ingredients to make a tasty , healthy meal .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Select ingredients that will be cooked after the same amount of time after they are cut up in appropriate sizes .

#Text=For example , raw chicken thighs , sliced celery , sliced carrots and peas , and a starch like diced potatoes or pasta with a sauce added , such as a can of condensed cream of chicken soup , would make a great dump recipe .
#Text=Remember to add additional liquid if you are including pasta in your recipe .
#Text=Follow the general approach to choosing your ingredients .
#Text=Here 's how you should go about this process :
#Text=Select the central ingredient , whether it be meat or fish or a vegan equivalent .
#Text=Select the vegetables and other ingredients , such as pasta , to go with it .
#Text=Decide on the size each ingredient will be to put in the cooker .
#Text=Search for relevant dump recipes online .
#Text=In fact , by searching for dump recipes , you may just come up with the ideal recipe you want and not have to create one yourself .
#Text=Select a cooking time which is appropriate to the container you are using .
#Text=Here 's what you need to know :
#Text=Stove cooking recipes containing chicken should take about 1/2 hour if at the boil .
#Text=A pressure cooker will take less time - perhaps 10 minutes on pressure .
#Text=A crockpot will take many hours - 4 hours on high and 6-8 hours on low .
#Text=Do n't forget to write down your recipe with cooking instructions .
#Text=This can help you repeat the delicious recipe at a later date , or to share it with friends .
#Text=And who knows , you may come up with a Dump Meal Recipe Book of your very own .
#Text=Currently , there are very few books like this available , and you could start a trend !
#Text=Tips
#Text=Depending on the cooking method you may need to add liquid like milk or water or stock .
#Text=For example , cooking in a pot on a stove requires additional liquid because of evaporation .
#Text=Using a pressure cooker should use little or no extra liquid .
#Text=Also remember that additions like pasta will require additional cooking liquid(s) .
#Text=It is better to have a little more liquid than necessary than not enough .
#Text=Use an instant read thermometer to check meat temperature - as long as the meat exceeds 175F you should be safe .
#Text=One-pot and casserole recipes are candidates for dump recipes .
#Text=If you size the recipe large enough , you will have leftovers which can serve as another meal or so ...
#Text=Some recipes you can portion out the ingredients into several containers or plastic food bags and freeze them ...
#Text=just remove the container(s)/bag(s ) you want and dump them into your cooking pot and cook until done .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Using raw or frozen meat(s) in a recipe can pose health dangers if the recipe is not cooked long enough .
#Text=Certain recipes require stirring the pot if cooking on a stove top .
#Text=Examples are recipes which include dairy and other ingredients which may tend to stick to the bottom of the pot .
#Text=When should I skip creating a dump recipe ?
#Text=Typically , recipes containing ingredients which may have widely differing cook times .
#Text=Or recipes which contain ingredient(s) which may be added to the other cooking ingredients in some order over time .
